question: In adults with chronic tension-type headache, is amitriptyline more effective than placebo in reducing headache frequency, duration, intensity, and analgesic use? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Amitriptyline significantly reduced (P < 0.05) frequency and duration of headache as well as analgesic consumption in chronic, but not in episodic, tension-type headache.
content.source_2: In a randomized controlled trial, tricyclic antidepressant medication and stress management therapy failed to exceed placebo in reducing headache activity, analgesic medication use, or headache-related disability, and antidepressant medication did not yield more rapid improvements in headache activity.
content.source_3: CONCLUSIONS Our results indicate that antidepressant medication and stress management therapy are each modestly effective in treating chronic tension-type headaches.
content.source_4: With a primary endpoint defined as a ≥50% reduction in the product of headache duration and frequency and in headache intensity, responder rates were higher on placebo (26.6%) than on amitriptyline (25.4%), with a significant difference favoring placebo (P < .05), indicating amitriptyline’s inferiority for chronic tension-type headache.
